get.description:
This request helps you track updates and changes in your account in the same way as in the [Audit Log](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/audit-log/). While the `Donations` endpoint shows the current state of a donation when queried, it doesn't reflect changes that happen after the initial creation (for example, finalized fees or status updates). The `Events` endpoint logs all updates as they occur, giving you the most current view of activity when you query it.

### Use cases
- **Retrieving finalized fees**. The `platform_fee` field in a donation will initially show 0 until Stripe finalizes the fee data. To get the updated fee values, use the `Events` endpoint to track the `donation.success` event, which confirms that the finalized fees have been updated.
- **Monitoring donation status changes**. Donations can move through multiple statuses — `pending`, `success`, `failed`, and more. Use the `Events` endpoint to track status changes. For example, a donation might be `pending` while awaiting payment processor confirmation and later transition to `success` or `failed`.
- **Tracking refunds and disputes**. If a donation is refunded or disputed, you'll receive corresponding events like `donation.refunded`, `donation.success_dispute_created`, or `donation.success_dispute_won`. This helps keep your records accurate without manually checking each donation.
- **Handling recurring plan updates**. Recurring donations generate events like `recurring_plan.activated`, `recurring_plan.failed`, or `recurring_plan.canceled`. Monitoring these events allows you to track subscription activities and take appropriate actions if a recurring payment fails or is canceled.
- **Updating supporter information**. When a supporter updates their information or requests personal data deletion, events like `supporter.updated` or `supporter.personal_data_deleted` are triggered. This is especially important for maintaining compliance with data protection regulations.
- **Monitoring tribute activity**. Use events like `tribute.created` or `tribute.updated` to keep track of tribute donations and ensure that tribute cards are sent as expected (`tribute.shared`).

parameters.name: starting_after
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `starting_after` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the last object in that list as the `starting_after` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the next page of results.

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `ending_before` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the first object in that list as the `ending_before` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the previous page of results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: This parameter specifies the number of records to display per page, ranging from 1 to 100.

parameters.name: types
parameters.description:
An optional array of up to 10 strings containing specific event types. The response will include only events with a matching type. Passing more than 10 values results in an error. Not passing this parameter will return all event types.

Available event types include donation events (for example, `donation.created`), recurring plan events (for example, `recurring_plan.activated`), transaction attempt events (for example, `transaction_attempt.success`), tribute events (for example, `tribute.created`), and supporter events (for example, `supporter.created`).

[Event types explained](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/audit-log/).

200.description: On success, the API returns the list of events. The response includes the event data array and a boolean indicating if more records are available.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access events.

post.description:
This request allows you to create either a one-time donation or a recurring plan. To create a recurring plan, you must include a `recurring_plan` object with the `frequency` parameter. If the object is not provided, a one-time donation will be created. All fields and values must meet the requirements of your campaign. Otherwise, an error will be returned. We do not format or verify addresses and emails that were sent through the API.

A Stripe payment method ID is required. For more details on how to create a payment method, refer to the Stripe Payment Methods documentation.

### Prerequisites Make sure you have: - A Stripe account that is connected to your Fundraise Up account and [activated](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/step-1/#creating-a-new-stripe-account). - An active campaign with a money-based payment method. - An API key with permission to create new donations. - Access to the Stripe API for the same Stripe account used as the Fundraise Up payment method, with the ability to [create Payment Methods](https://docs.stripe.com/api/payment_methods). Nonprofit organizations must meet PCI compliance requirements to ensure the secure processing of payment card data. Fundraise Up complies with these standards, but if an organization or its vendor uses direct API integration with Stripe to send raw card data (such as card numbers, expiration dates, and CVV codes), that organization or vendor is responsible for meeting broader PCI DSS requirements, such as SAQ D for merchants or higher. When using [Stripe Elements](https://docs.stripe.com/payments/elements), organizations remain responsible for PCI compliance, but the scope is reduced, typically to SAQ A, due to Stripe handling sensitive card data processing. If a third-party vendor manages card details (for example, in face-to-face or direct mail solutions), they must maintain their own PCI compliance (SAQ D or applicable), and the organization should document them as their third-party service provider.

200.description: On success, the API returns the donation object. If the parameters are invalid, the call will return an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access donations.

get.description:
This request lets you access donation records in your Fundraise Up account. Note that we do not support webhooks.

The supporter data will be displayed as it appears on the Donation page in your Dashboard.

parameters.name: starting_after
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `starting_after` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the last object in that list as the `starting_after` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the next page of results.

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `ending_before` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the first object in that list as the `ending_before` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the previous page of results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: This parameter specifies the number of records to display per page, ranging from 1 to 100.

200.description: On success, the API returns the array of donation objects. If the parameters are invalid, the call will return an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access donations.

post.description:
This request allows you to update the details of a donation that was made through an API call. You can make updates to: * Enrich data. * Modify parameter values. * Remove parameter values.

This action is only available within 24 hours of the donation being created.

Donations created outside of the API, such as through the Checkout modal, Campaign Page, or Virtual Terminal, cannot be edited through the API.

The donation ID must belong to the account associated with the API key. Donations from subaccounts cannot be updated using the API key of the parent account. Attempting to do so will result in an error. To update a donation in a subaccount, you must use the API key of that subaccount. For the update to be successful, the donation object must match the current campaign settings, otherwise the operation will fail with a validation error. Parallel requests to update one object are not allowed and will result in an error. Any parameters or child parameters that are not provided will remain unchanged. A successful update will modify the donation receipt, but no emails will be sent as a result. If you update recurring plan, the changes will apply to both the specific installment and all future installments.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the donation, formatted as D[A-Z]{7}.

200.description: On success, the API returns the donation object. If the parameters are invalid, the call will return an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to update donations.

post.summary: Update a donation and its associated recurring plan

This request lets you access donation records in your Fundraise Up account. Note that we do not support webhooks.

The supporter data will be displayed as it appears on the Donation page in your Dashboard.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the donation, formatted as D[A-Z]{7}.

200.description: On success, the API returns the donation object. If the parameters are invalid, the call will return an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access donations.

get.description:
Use this request to retrieve a paginated list of supporter records from your Fundraise Up account. Each record includes the latest contact details and other supporter-level fields, matching the data shown in the Supporters view in the Dashboard.

## About supporter contact data

The `address`, `phone`, and `employer` fields in supporter records reflect the most recent information provided by the supporter.

These fields are updated automatically when:

* The supporter makes a new donation using the same email address.
* A donation or recurring plan is edited in the Dashboard.
* The supporter updates their details in the Donor Portal.

Installments do not update supporter-level contact data.

You can't edit supporter contact fields through the API. To change them, update the associated donation or recurring plan — in the Dashboard at any time, or through the API within 24 hours of creation. The supporter record will reflect the updated values automatically.

This behavior applies only to changes made after June 2, 2025. Data collected earlier is not updated retroactively.

### Tracking updates using the Events endpoint

To monitor changes to supporter contact data, use the [Events endpoint](https://api.fundraiseup.com/v1/docs/#/operations/GetEvents). The following events may indicate a change to supporter contact fields:

* `supporter.updated` — supporter-level data has changed.
* `donation.updated` — contact fields on a donation were modified.
* `recurring_plan.details_updated` — a recurring plan was edited.

When you receive one of these events, use the corresponding endpoints to retrieve updated data:

* `GET /supporters/{id}` — get supporter-level contact information.
* `GET /donations/{id}` — get contact details specific to a donation.
* `GET /recurring_plans/{id}` — get contact details specific to a recurring plan.

parameters.name: starting_after
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `starting_after` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the last object in that list as the `starting_after` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the next page of results.

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `ending_before` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the first object in that list as the `ending_before` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the previous page of results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: This parameter specifies the number of records to display per page, ranging from 1 to 100.

200.description: On success, the API returns the list of supporters.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access supporters.

get.description:
Use this request to retrieve a specific supporter record by its unique ID. The response includes all supporter-level fields available in the Dashboard, such as name, email, language, mailing address, phone number, employer, and others.

 ## About supporter contact data

The `address`, `phone`, and `employer` fields in supporter records reflect the most recent information provided by the supporter.

These fields are updated automatically when:
- The supporter makes a new donation using the same email address.
- A donation or recurring plan is edited in the Dashboard.
- The supporter updates their details in the Donor Portal.

Installments do not update supporter-level contact data.

You can't edit supporter contact fields through the API. To change them, update the associated donation or recurring plan. The supporter record will reflect the updated values automatically.

This behavior applies only to changes made after June 2, 2025. Data collected earlier is not updated retroactively.

### Tracking updates using the Events endpoint

To monitor changes to supporter contact data, use the [Events endpoint](https://api.fundraiseup.com/v1/docs/#/operations/GetEvents). The following events may indicate a change to supporter contact fields:

- `supporter.updated` — supporter-level data has changed.
- `donation.updated` — contact fields on a donation were modified.
- `recurring_plan.details_updated` — a recurring plan was edited.

When you receive one of these events, use the corresponding endpoints to retrieve updated data:
- `GET /supporters/{id}` — get supporter-level contact information.
- `GET /donations/{id}` — get contact details specific to a donation.
- `GET /recurring_plans/{id}` — get contact details specific to a recurring plan.

post.description: This request allows you to create a Fundraiser — a supporter-led fundraising page connected to a specific campaign. Learn more about [how Fundraisers work](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/fundraiser/) in Fundraise Up.

200.description: On success, the API returns the created Fundraiser object. If any parameters are invalid, the request returns an error response.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to create Fundraisers.

get.description: This request allows you to retrieve Fundraiser records from your Fundraise Up account. Webhooks are not supported.

parameters.name: starting_after
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `starting_after` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the last object in that list as the `starting_after` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the next page of results.

parameters.name: ending_before
parameters.description: A cursor for pagination. The `ending_before` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the first object in that list as the `ending_before` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the previous page of results.

parameters.description: This parameter specifies the number of records to display per page, ranging from 1 to 100.

200.description: On success, the API returns an array of Fundraiser objects. If parameters are invalid, the request returns an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to access Fundraisers.

post.description:
This request allows you to update the details of a Fundraiser.

You can make updates to:

* Enrich data.
* Modify parameter values.
* Remove parameter values.

The Fundraiser ID must belong to the account associated with the API key.

Fundraisers from subaccounts cannot be updated using the API key of the parent account. Attempting to do so will result in an error. To update a Fundraiser in a subaccount, you must use the API key of that subaccount.

For the update to succeed, the Fundraiser object must match the current campaign settings; otherwise, the operation will fail with a validation error.

Parallel requests to update the same object are not allowed and will result in an error.

Any parameters or child parameters that are not included will remain unchanged.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the Fundraiser, formatted as N[A-Z]{7}.

200.description: On success, the API returns the Fundraiser object. If parameters are invalid, the call will return an error.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to update Fundraisers.

get.description: This request allows you to retrieve a Fundraiser record from your Fundraise Up account. Webhooks are not supported.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of the Fundraiser, formatted as N[A-Z]{7}.

post.description: This request generates a link that allows a specific supporter to access their Fundraise Up Donor Portal page without logging in. Read more about [integrating Fundraise Up Donor Portal with your platform](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/seamless-donor-portal/).

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the supporter, formatted as S[A-Z]{7}.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to perform this operation.

post.summary: Create a Donor Portal access link for a supporter

post.description:
This request generates a link that allows a supporter to view and edit a specific recurring plan. Access to other sections of the Fundraise Up Donor Portal is restricted.

Parent accounts cannot use their API keys to create Donor Portal access links for subaccounts. To create access links for a subaccount, generate an API key within that specific subaccount and use it.

Read more about [integrating Fundraise Up Donor Portal with your platform](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/seamless-donor-portal/).

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the recurring plan in the format R[A-Z]{7}.

200.description: Successful response containing the generated donor portal access link.

403.description: Forbidden. The API key does not have permission to perform this operation.

post.summary: Create a Donor Portal access link for a recurring plan

info.title: Fundraise Up API
info.description:
1. [Overview](#/#overview) 2. [Limitations](#/#limitations) 3. [Key features](#/#key-features) 4. [Use cases](#/#use-cases) 5. [How to get API key](#/#how-to-get-api-key) 6. [Managing API keys](#/#managing-api-keys) 7. [Authentication](#/#authentication) 8. [Parent accounts and subaccounts](#/#parent-accounts-and-subaccounts) 9. [Rate limits](#/#rate-limits) 10. [Errors](#/#errors) 11. [Pagination](#/#pagination) 12. [Request IDs](#/#request-ids) 13. [Changes in API](#/#changes-in-api) ## Overview The Fundraise Up API gives you more control over your fundraising data. Use it to process offline donations through your Fundraise Up account and keep your CRM or other systems up to date with your fundraising activity. With the API, you can interact with these resources: - Donations — Create and update donations and their associated recurring plans (within 24 hours of creation, API-created only). - Recurring plans — Read recurring donation schedules. - Supporters — Access supporter details. - Events — Retrieve events from your Audit Log. - Donor Portal access links — Authenticate supporters in the Donor Portal. - Donor Portal recurring plan access links — Provide direct access to recurring plan settings. ## Limitations - The API does not support bulk updates — each request can only create or update one object. - Updates to Donations and Recurring plans are restricted to the first 24 hours and apply only to API-created donations. - You can retrieve and export data only for Donations, Recurring plans, Supporters, and Events. - The API supports card-based payment methods only: credit cards, debit cards, Apple Pay, and Google Pay. Other methods are not supported. ## Key features - Architecture — Built on REST principles. - URLs — Provides predictable, resource-oriented URLs. - Requests — Accepts JSON-encoded request bodies with `Content-Type: application/json` header. - Responses — Returns JSON-encoded responses. - Standards — Uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs. ## Use cases There are a variety of use cases where you can integrate our API into your fundraising flow. In particular, you can use our API for: - Ticketing and events. - Face-to-face fundraising. - Direct mail campaigns. - Telefundraising. - Fundraising galas and dinners. - Analytics integrations. The API is not intended for migrating subscriptions from legacy systems. For migration purposes, please refer to our [Migration service](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/migration/). ## How to get API key To use the Fundraise Up API, you first need to generate an API key. Only users with the [Organization Administrator](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/team-settings/#organization-administrator) role can create and manage API keys. Follow these steps to create your API key: 1. Go to **[Dashboard](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/)** > **Settings** > **API keys**. 2. Click **Create API key**. 3. Enter a descriptive name for your API key. This name helps you identify different keys when you have multiple integrations. 4. Choose the operating mode for your key: - **Test data**: Use this mode to test your integration. You can later identify test mode keys by their `test_` prefix. They don't affect your live data or banking networks. - **Live data**: Use this mode for processing real donations. Live mode keys have no prefix. 5. Set permissions for this key by selecting at least one. You can modify these permissions later using the three-dot menu next to the key. - **Retrieve donation data**: To access your organization's donation information. - **Create new donations**: To process donations through your integration. - **Retrieve fundraiser data**: To access supporter-created [Fundraisers](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/fundraiser/) linked to your campaigns. - **Create new fundraisers**: To create Fundraiser records through your integration. - **Generate Donor Portal access links**: To create secure [login links](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/seamless-donor-portal/) for your supporters. 6. Click **Create API key**. 7. Copy and securely store your API key. You will only see it once and cannot retrieve it later. Your key is activated immediately and does not expire. ![Name.png](https://ucarecdn.com/91bd1878-cb29-47b4-8213-e4829cf149a1/api-1.png) ## Managing API keys You can view all your API keys on the [API keys page](http://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/settings/api-keys). For each key, click the three-dot menu to manage its settings. You can edit the key name, modify its permissions, or delete it if you no longer need it. If you're using a third-party provider to manage your donations, they must have permission to create [Payment Method](https://docs.stripe.com/api/payment_methods) entities in the same Stripe account as Fundraise Up.

If you suspect that your API key has been compromised, delete it immediately and generate a new key.

## Authentication Authenticate to the API using HTTP Bearer authentication. Include your API key in the `Authorization` header like this: `curl -H "Authorization: Bearer test_…"`. Ensure that all API requests are made over HTTPS. Requests made over HTTP will not be accepted. Requests without proper authentication will also be rejected. ## Parent accounts and subaccounts Each API key allows you to create donations only for the account to which it belongs. Parent accounts cannot create donations and generate [Donor Portal access links](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/seamless-donor-portal/) for subaccounts using their parent API key. To create donations for a subaccount, you need to generate an API key within that specific subaccount and use it. However, the parent account can still view and manage all API keys, including those for subaccounts. Additionally, a parent account's API key can export data for both the parent account and its subaccounts. This makes it easy to keep track of both API key activity and export data across the parent account and its subaccounts. ![Parent accounts and subaccounts.png](https://ucarecdn.com/07b2584a-7a8d-43f9-9be6-832b02d2f04a/api-2.png) ## Rate limits To maintain stability and ensure reliable performance, the Fundraise Up API uses a concurrency-based request limit. ### Concurrency limit Each account can send up to 3 API requests in parallel. This applies to all endpoints and all API keys associated with the same account, whether test or live. When more than 3 requests are sent in parallel, only 3 will be processed. Any additional requests will be rejected with a `429 Too Many Requests` error and the code `concurrent_requests_limit_exceeded`. To avoid hitting the limit: - Keep your integration single-threaded and run requests sequentially — one after another. - If you use parallel requests, implement a queue to control concurrency. ### Subaccounts The limit applies to each account individually. Parent and subaccounts are counted separately. If your setup requires more parallel processing, you can distribute requests across multiple subaccounts. ## Errors Fundraise Up uses standard HTTP response codes to indicate the outcome of an API request: - `2xx` codes indicate successful requests. - `4xx` codes indicate client-side errors, such as missing parameters or failed charges. - `5xx` codes, which are rare, indicate server-side issues with Fundraise Up. Certain 4xx errors, such as a [declined card](https://docs.stripe.com/declines), will include an error code with a brief explanation. ## HTTP status codes | Code | Status | Explanation | | ------------------ | ----------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | 200 | OK | Everything worked as expected. | | 400 | Bad Request | The request was invalid, typically due to a missing required parameter. | | 401 | Unauthorized | No valid API key provided. | | 403 | Forbidden | The API key doesn't have permissions to perform the request. | | 404 | Not Found | The requested resource doesn't exist. | | 409 | Conflict | The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the resource. This usually indicates a concurrency issue. | | 429 | Too Many Requests | Your organization has exceeded the allowed number of concurrent requests. Reduce the number of simultaneous requests to avoid this error. | | 500, 502, 503, 504 | Server Errors | Something went wrong on the Fundraise Up side. (These are rare.) | ### Attributes - `code`**: nullable string.** Short error code for some errors that can be handled programmatically. - `message`**: nullable string.** Human-readable error description. - `parameter`**: nullable string.** Parameter associated with the error. - `stripe_error`**: nullable dictionary.** Stripe-specific error details (see [Stripe API documentation](https://docs.stripe.com/api/errors).) ### Error codes | Error code | Explanation | | ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------- | | `tokens_rate_limit_exceeded` | Too many API tokens used within a time period. | | `requests_rate_limit_exceeded` | Organization has reached the limit for API requests per period. | | `concurrent_requests_limit_exceeded` | Account has too many parallel requests. | | `stripe_rate_limit_exceeded` | Too many requests made to Stripe. | | `stripe_error` | Error related to Stripe payment processing. | | `not_found` | Requested resource could not be found. | | `update_expired` | Update attempted after the allowed time period. | | `update_conflict` | The request conflicts with another request. | | `parameter_unexpected` | Unexpected parameter provided in the request. | | `parameter_required` | Required parameter is missing from the request. | | `parameter_invalid` | Parameter provided is not valid. | | `payment_account_required` | Payment account setup is necessary. | Error codes may change over time. We'll update this article to reflect any changes. ## Pagination All API endpoints that list records display them in reverse chronological order and use cursor-based navigation for browsing through the list. To maintain consistent sorting and navigation, especially when entities have the same creation date, records are also sorted by identifier in reverse alphabetical order. This means that records are first sorted by creation date (newest to oldest), and then by identifier (Z to A). | **Parameter** | **Type** | **Description** | | ---------------- | --------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `limit` | **optional**, 10 by default | This parameter specifies the number of records to display per page, ranging from 1 to 100. | | `starting_after` | **optional object ID** | A cursor for pagination. The `starting_after` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the last object in that list as the `starting_after` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the next page of results. | | `ending_before` | **optional object ID** | A cursor for pagination. The `ending_before` parameter uses an existing object ID to define your position in the list. For example, if you fetch a list of items and receive 100 results, you can use the ID of the first object in that list as the `ending_before` parameter in your subsequent request to retrieve the previous page of results. | The parameters `starting_after` and `ending_before` are mutually exclusive. | **List response format** | **Type** | **Description** | | ------------------------ | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | `data` | **array** | An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters. | | `has_more` | **boolean** | Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records. | ### How to get records for a specific date range The API does not support date-based filtering through query parameters. To get records from a specific time period (for example, donations from December), you’ll need to: 1. Use cursor-based pagination to fetch records in reverse chronological order: ``` GET /v1/donations?limit=100 # Use the last donation ID from the response to get the next page GET /v1/donations?limit=100&starting_after=LAST_DONATION_ID ``` 2. Filter the records in your application by checking the `created_at` timestamp and keeping only those that fall within your target date range. Since records are returned from newest to oldest, you can stop paginating once you reach records older than your date range. ## Request IDs Each API request includes response header `Request-Id` with unique value. To help us resolve issues faster, please include the `Request-Id` when contacting us about a specific request. ## Changes in API We prioritize stability and compatibility in our API. We aim to make all changes backwards-compatible within the current version to avoid disrupting your existing workflows. If a change requires incompatibility, we will release a new API version. Detailed information about any changes will be posted on this page and added to the documentation. ### July 2025 #### Bank account details now included in payment object The payment object in the `/v1/donations` response now includes a new `bank_account` object. This object is returned when the payment method is a bank transfer (such as ACH or SEPA Direct Debit) and includes a `last4` field with the last four digits of the bank account number. This addition mirrors the existing `credit_card` object and provides more complete data for reconciliation and reporting. No changes are required on your end unless you wish to make use of the new field. #### New field: supporter_covered_fee_in_default_currency A new field, `supporter_covered_fee_in_default_currency`, has been added to the `/v1/donations` response. It represents the equivalent of `supporter_covered_fee` in the organization’s default currency, providing better clarity for cross-currency donations. The description of `supporter_covered_fee` was also updated to clarify that the amount is in the donation’s currency. ### June 2025 #### New concurrency limit for API requests We’ve updated how rate limits work in the API. Instead of per-second or per-minute thresholds, the API now enforces a concurrency-based limit: each account can have up to 3 active requests at the same time. If this limit is exceeded, additional requests are rejected with a `429 Too Many Requests` error. #### Automatic updates for supporter contact data The address, phone, and employer fields in the `/v1/supporters` and `/v1/supporters/{id}` responses now reflect the latest data submitted through donations and recurring plans. To track changes, use the `supporter.updated`, `donation.updated`, and `recurring_plan.details_updated` events from the `/v1/events endpoint`. ### May 2025 #### Expanded data in recurring_plan object The `recurring_plan` object in the `/v1/donations` response now includes `created_at`, `ended_at`, and `next_installment_at` fields. This helps reduce the need for separate API calls to `/v1/recurring_plans/{id}`. ### April 2025 #### New endpoint: Fundraisers We’ve added a new `fundraisers` endpoint to the API. This endpoint lets you create, update, and retrieve supporter-created Fundraisers linked to your campaigns.

tags.name: Access links
tags.description: The Access link object represents link that grant supporter access to their Donor Portal.

tags.name: Donations
tags.description:
The Donation object represents a single donation. It can be either a one-time donation or an installment as part of a recurring plan.

You can create donations, update donations and associated recurring plans sourced from the API, and read donations from your account.

tags.name: Events
tags.description: The Event object represents each entry in your Audit Log, allowing you to track changes in your account.

tags.name: Fundraisers
tags.description: The Fundraiser object represents a supporter-created fundraising page linked to a campaign. You can create Fundraisers through the API, update them, and retrieve Fundraisers from your account.

tags.name: Recurring plans
tags.description: The Recurring Plan object represents a single recurring donation plan. It includes supporter data, which is displayed as it appears on the Recurring Plan page in your Dashboard.

tags.name: Supporters
tags.description: The Supporter object represents a single supporter record. It includes data as displayed on the Supporter page in your Dashboard.

code.description: Custom identifier for the organization, set as the Account code in the Fundraise Up account.

id.description: Unique identifier of the organization in the format A[A-Z]{7}.

name.description: The name of the organization as set in the Fundraise Up account.

region.description: Can refer to a region, state, or province.

last4.description: Last four digits of the bank account number.

BankAccountResponse.description: Contains information about the bank account used for the payment.

BenefitOption.description: Benefit option selected by the supporter.

code.description: Campaign code, as set in the Dashboard.

email.description: Email associated with the payment method.

error_message.description: Most recent payment error message. Returned only if the status is `failed` or `retrying`. Otherwise, returns `null`.

id.description:
For PayPal: Capture ID.

For Stripe: Charge ID or Payment Intent ID.

For other processors: payment ID.

method.description:
Payment method, in lowercase underscore. `stock` is deprecated but may still appear in retrieved data.

The value of `us_bank_account` maps to `ach`. The value of `plaid` also maps to `ach`.

processor.description: Payment processor, in lowercase. `coinbase_commerce` is deprecated but may still appear in retrieved data.

ChargePaymentResponse.description: Provides details about the payment processing.

general.description:
Indicates overall communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive communications.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined communications.

`not_submitted` if no consent data is available.

CommunicationConsentResponse.description: Stores the supporter's [communication consent type](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/marketing-consent/) associated with a donation.

amount.description:
Donation amount in the selected currency. Must be a decimal string in the format `{NNN}[.nn]`. Examples: 9.99 (for USD), 200 (for JPY).

The amount must be greater than $1 or its equivalent in other currencies. If a minimum amount is set for the campaign, the donation must meet or exceed that value.

campaign.description: Campaign ID. Must belong to the account that owns the API key, otherwise an error will occur. Must be active and accept money-based donations, otherwise an error will occur.

designation.description:
The ID of the fund, program, or initiative the donation goes to. You can use the ID of any designation created in your account, whether or not it is linked to a campaign.
Only one designation can be set for a single donation. To create multiple donations with different designations, make separate API calls.
You can find the ID in the [Designations section of the Dashboard](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/designations).

skip_thank_you_email.description:
`false` (default) will send a donation receipt email for the first installment.

`true` will prevent the donation receipt email from being sent for the first installment.

Available for recurring plans only.

To use this parameter, you must also include the `email` parameter.

Sending this parameter for a one-time donation will return an error.

CreateDonationRequest.description: Contains the request parameters required for creating a donation.

campaign.description: Campaign ID. Must belong to the account that owns the API key, otherwise an error will occur. The campaign must be active and accept money-based donations, otherwise an error will occur.

description.example: I'm raising money to help protect penguins and their habitat. Join me!

name.description: The title of the Fundraiser, used as its main heading.

code.description: Identifier of up to 150 characters. Does not need to be unique.

slug.description: Unique identifier for the Fundraiser within the account or subaccount. The slug is not shared across accounts or subaccounts and must be unique within each. Can include up to 25 letters, numbers, underscores, or hyphens.

CreateFundraiserRequest.description: Contains the request parameters required for creating a Fundraiser.

last4.description: Last four digits of the credit card number.

CreditCardResponse.description: Contains information about the credit card used for the payment.

CustomFieldPostRequest.description:
Represents custom fields populated according to the campaign settings.

Missing fields will be populated with default non-blank values from the campaign settings.

CustomFieldPutRequest.description:
Represents custom fields populated according to the campaign settings.

Missing fields will be populated with default non-blank values from the campaign settings.

CustomFieldResponse.description:
Represents custom fields populated according to the campaign settings.

Missing fields will be populated with default non-blank values from the campaign settings.

email.description:
Indicates email communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive emails.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined email communication.

`not_submitted` if no email consent data is available.

phone_calls.description:
Indicates phone call communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive phone calls.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined to receive phone calls.

`not_submitted` if no phone call consent data is available.

postal_mail.description:
Indicates postal mail communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive postal mail.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined to receive postal mail.

`not_submitted` if no postal mail consent data is available.

sms.description:
Indicates SMS communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive SMS messages.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined SMS communication.

`not_submitted` if no SMS consent data is available.

social_media.description:
Indicates social media communication consent.

`opted_in` if the supporter agreed to receive messages through social media.

`opted_out` if the supporter declined social media communication.

`not_submitted` if no social media consent data is available.

CustomizedCommunicationConsentResponse.description: Specifies consent values for individual communication channels.

code.description: Designation code, as set in the Dashboard.

browser.description: Browser name. Can be `null` if not detected.

os.description: Operating system name. Can be `null` if not detected.

type.description: Device type. Can be `null` if not detected.

DeviceResponse.description: Provides information about the device used for making the donation.

created_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the recurring plan was created in UTC.

ended_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the recurring plan ended in UTC.

id.description: Unique identifier for the recurring donation plan.

next_installment_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating the next scheduled donation installment in UTC.

status.description: Current status of the recurring plan.

DonationRecurringPlanResponse.description: Defines the attributes of a recurring donation plan.

amount.description: Donation amount in the transaction currency.

amount_before_fees_covered.description: Amount before fees were covered by supporter.

amount_before_fees_covered_in_default_cu.description: Donation amount before any fees were covered by the supporter. Displayed in the organization's default currency at the time of donation.

amount_in_default_currency.description: Donation amount converted to the organization's default currency.

anonymous.description: Indicates if the donation was made anonymously (`true`) or not (`false`).

comment.description: Optional comment provided by the supporter at the time of donation.

created_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the donation was created in UTC.

failed_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the donation failed in UTC.

installment.description: Indicates the installment number for recurring donations. Returns `null` for one-time donations.

livemode.description: Test mode indicator. `true` for live mode donations, `false` for test mode donations.

on_behalf_of.description: Name of the organization the donation was made on behalf of.

receipt_id.description: Unique identifier for the donation receipt.

refunded_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the donation was refunded in UTC.

source.description: Indicates the source of the donation.

succeeded_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the donation succeeded in UTC.

supporter_covered_fee.description: Amount of fees covered by the supporter.

supporter_covered_fee_in_default_currenc.description: Amount of fees covered by the supporter and converted to the organization's default currency.

url.description: URL from which the donation was made.

DonationResponse.description: Contains donation record with all donation details.

data.description: An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records.

DonationsResponse.description: Provides a paginated response for donations.

url.description:
Authentication link for the Donor Portal. Must be a valid URL starting with `http://` or `https://`. If invalid, a `400 Bad Request error` will occur.

This URL appears as the "← Back to home" link in the Donor Portal. The supporter can click this link or the portal logo to return to your organization's portal.

If not provided, the "← Back to home" button will not appear and the portal logo will not be clickable.

DonorAuthLinkResponse.description: Contains the response for a generated Donor Portal authentication link.

type.description: Type of element used for the donation.

ElementResponse.description: Represents the element through which the donation was made.

EmbeddedSupporterResponse.description: Represents the supporter data as displayed on the Donation page in your Dashboard.

created_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the event was created in UTC.

donation.description: Unique ID of the related donation. Example event: `donation.created`.

livemode.description: Test mode indicator. `true` for live mode donations, `false` for test mode donations.

recurring_plan.description: Unique ID of the related recurring plan. Example event: `recurring_plan.created`.

supporter.description: Unique ID of the related supporter. Example events: `donation.personal_data_deleted`.

type.description:
Type of event that occurred in the system. Include donation events (for example, `donation.created`), recurring plan events (for example, `recurring_plan.activated`), transaction attempt events (for example, `transaction_attempt.success`), tribute events (for example, `tribute.created`), and supporter events (for example, `supporter.created`).

[Event types explained](https://fundraiseup.com/docs/audit-log/)

EventResponse.description: Provides detailed information about a specific event that occurred in the system, such as donation creation or recurring plan updates.

data.description: An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records.

EventsResponse.description: Contains the response for a list of events, including paginated event data and metadata indicating if more records are available.

end_date.description: End date for the fundraiser goal.

FundraiserGoalResponse.description: Goal details for the Fundraiser, if set.

upload_url.description: The URL of the fundraiser's image. The image must be a accessible with no authentication and validation.

FundraiserImageResponse.description: Image details for the Fundraiser, if available.

name.description: The title of the Fundraiser, used as its main heading.

data.description: An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records.

FundraisersResponse.description: Provides a paginated response for fundraisers.

code.description: Code for the fundraiser, if applicable.

name.description: The title of the Fundraiser, used as its main heading.

slug.description: Slug for the Fundraiser, if set.

GetFundraiserResponse.description: Represents a Fundraiser entry in the API.

claimed.description: Indicates whether the Gift Aid was claimed (`true`) or not (`false`).

legal_text.description: Legal text associated with Gift Aid.
legal_text.example: I am a UK taxpayer and want to claim Gift Aid.

GiftAidResponse.description: Provides details about Gift Aid, available only for organizations based in Great Britain.

amount.description:
Donation amount in the selected currency. Must be a decimal string in the format `{NNN}[.nn]`. Examples: 9.99 (for USD), 200 (for JPY).

The amount must be greater than $10 or its equivalent in other currencies.

end_date.description: Date when the goal ends. Must be in YYYY-MM-DD format and set to a future date.

IpResponse.description: Contains details about the IP address from which the donation was made.

PaymentMethodPostRequest.description: Provides details about the payment method used.

id.description: The [PaymentMethod ID](https://docs.stripe.com/api/payment_methods/object#payment_method_object-id) within the organization's Stripe account. Supported payment methods are credit cards, debit cards, Apple Pay, and Google Pay.

PaymentMethodStripePostRequest.description:
Contains information about the Stripe payment method used for the transaction.

When writing test code, use a `payment_method.stripe.id` such as `pm_card_visa` from the list of [Stripe test cards](https://docs.stripe.com/testing?testing-method=payment-methods#cards). For more information on using test cards, see the [Stripe documentation](https://docs.stripe.com/testing?testing-method=payment-methods#use-test-cards).

amount.description: Payout amount in the donation's currency.

amount_in_default_currency.description: Payout amount in the organization's default currency at the time of donation.

PayoutResponse.description: Contains information about the payout details.

amount.description: Platform fee amount in the donation's currency.

amount_in_default_currency.description: Platform fee amount converted to the organization's default currency at the time of the donation.

PlatformFeeResponse.description:
Provides details about the platform fee charged by Fundraise Up.

The `platform_fee` field will return 0 until Stripe provides the finalized fee data, which may take some time after a successful donation. To retrieve the finalized fee values, use the `Events` endpoint. Look for the `donation.success` event, which confirms that the calculated fees have been updated by Stripe.

amount.description: Processing fee amount in the donation's currency.

amount_in_default_currency.description: Platform fee amount converted to the organization’s default currency at the time of the donation.

ProcessingFeeResponse.description:
Contains information about the processing fee charged by the payment processor.

The `processing_fee` field will return 0 until Stripe provides the finalized fee data, which may take some time after a successful donation. To retrieve the finalized fee values, use the `Events` endpoint. Look for the `donation.success` event, which confirms that the calculated fees have been updated by Stripe.

id.description: Unique identifier of the question, formatted as Q[A-Z]{7}. Located in [Settings > Questions](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/settings/questions).

checked.description: Indicates whether the checkbox is checked. Required for questions with the type “Single checkbox.”.

date.description: Answer for the question in date format (YYYY-MM-DD). Required for questions with the type “Date”.

options.description: List of selected options. Required for question types “Multiple checkboxes”.

text.description: Answer for the question, maximum 256 characters. Required for questions with types “Text box”, “Text line”, “Select one option”, and “Dropdown menu”.

QuestionPostRequest.description: Represents an answer to a question in the donation process. Required if the campaign settings include mandatory questions.

id.description: Unique identifier of the question, formatted as Q[A-Z]{7}. Located in [Settings > Questions.](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/settings/questions).

checked.description: Indicates whether the checkbox is selected. Required for question types “Checkbox”.

date.description: Answer for the question in date format (YYYY-MM-DD). Required for questions with the type “Date”.

options.description: List of selected options. Required for question types “Select multiple options” or “Checkbox”.

text.description: Answer for the question, maximum 256 characters. Required for questions with types “Text box”, “Text line”, “Select one option”, and “Dropdown menu”.

QuestionPutRequest.description:
Represents an update to an answer in the donation process. Required if the campaign settings include mandatory questions.

Submitting a new request erases all previous answers to all questions and sets the answers to the new values.

code.description: Question code, as set in the Dashboard.

id.description: Unique identifier of the question, formatted as Q[A-Z]{7}. Located in [Settings > Questions](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/settings/questions).

checked.description: Indicates whether the checkbox is selected. Required for questions with the type "Single checkbox".

options.description: List of selected options. Required for questions with the type "Multiple checkboxes".

text.description: Answer for the question. This field is returned only for question types "Text box", "Text line", "Select one option", and "Dropdown menu".

QuestionResponse.description:
Provides information about a question used in the donation process.

Each item must include an `id` and, depending on the question type, one of the following fields: `text`, `options`, or `checked`.

region.description: Can refer to a region, state, or province.

RecipientAddressResponse.description: Provides the postal address for the tribute recipient.

email.description: Email associated with the payment method.

error_message.description: Most recent payment error message. Returned only if the status is `failed` or `retrying`. Otherwise, returns `null`.

method.description:
Payment method, in lowercase underscore. `stock` is deprecated but may still appear in retrieved data.

The value of `us_bank_account` maps to `ach`. The value of `plaid` also maps to `ach`.

processor.description: Payment processor, in lowercase. `coinbase_commerce` is deprecated but may still appear in retrieved data.

RecurringPaymentResponse.description: Provides details about the payment processing.

RecurringPlanDeviceResponse.description: Contains device information used in recurring plan creation.

amount.description: Donation amount for each recurring installment, in the plan's currency.

amount_before_fees_covered.description: Amount before fees were covered by supporter.

amount_before_fees_covered_in_default_cu.description: Amount before fees were covered by supporter, converted to the organization's default currency at the time of the donation.

amount_in_default_currency.description: Donation amount for each recurring installment, converted to the organization's default currency at the time of the donation.

anonymous.description: Indicates if the recurring donations are made anonymously (`true`) or not (`false`).

comment.description: Optional comment attached to the recurring donation plan.

created_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the recurring plan was created in UTC.

ended_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the recurring plan ended in UTC.

id.description: Unique identifier for the recurring donation plan.

livemode.description: Test mode indicator. `true` for recurring plans in live mode, `false` for recurring plans in test mode.

next_installment_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating the next scheduled donation installment in UTC.

on_behalf_of.description: Name of the organization the donation was made on behalf of.

source.description: Source of the recurring donation setup.

supporter_covered_fee.description: Amount of fees covered by the supporter.

supporter_covered_fee_in_default_currenc.description: Amount of fees covered by the supporter and converted to the organization's default currency.

url.description: URL where the recurring donation was set up.

RecurringPlanResponse.description: Contains details about a recurring plan.

data.description: An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records.

RecurringPlansResponse.description: Provides a response for recurring plans.

frequency.description: Recurring plan frequency. Determines how often a recurring donation is processed.

RecurringPostRequest.description:
Defines the parameters for a recurring donation plan.

This must be specified if the campaign settings in the Frequency section do not include "Once" as an option for either Default Frequency or Second Frequency.

line1.description: The first line of the supporter's mailing address, typically including the street address. Maximum 256 characters.

line2.description: The second line of the supporter's mailing address, typically including the street address. Maximum 256 characters.

region.description:
Supporter's region. Maximum 64 characters.

Required for all countries except `gb` (United Kingdom), `il` (Israel), `nl` (Netherlands), `fr` (France), `de` (Germany). Can be: region, state, or province.

SupporterAddressPostRequest.description:
Represents the mailing address of the supporter.

This field is required if the campaign requires a mailing address, based on the "Ask for mailing address" setting and the minimum amount that triggers the request.

line1.description: The first line of the supporter's mailing address, typically including the street address. Maximum 256 characters.

line2.description: The second line of the supporter's mailing address, typically including the street address. Maximum 256 characters.

region.description:
Supporter's region. Maximum 64 characters.

Required for all countries except `gb` (United Kingdom), `il` (Israel), `nl` (Netherlands), `fr` (France), `de` (Germany). Can be: region, state, or province.

SupporterAddressPutRequest.description:
Represents the mailing address of the supporter.

This field is required if the campaign requires a mailing address, based on the “Ask for mailing address” setting and the minimum amount that triggers the request.

To remove the address, pass `null` for `supporter.address`.

name.description: The name of the organization or company where the supporter works. Maximum 64 characters.

SupporterEmployerPostRequest.description: Contains information about the supporter's employer.

name.description: The name of the organization or company where the supporter works. Maximum 64 characters.

SupporterEmployerPutRequest.description: Contains information about the supporter's employer.

phone.description:
Supporter's phone number. Maximum 20 characters.

Only included if the campaign setting “Ask for phone number” is enabled.

Required if the campaign is configured to require the supporter to provide their phone number.

title.description:
Supporter's title in lowercase. Available options depend on the campaign settings. Available for the following countries:

- **United Kingdom:** `mr`, `mrs`, `miss`, `ms`, `mx`, `sir`, `dr`, `rev`, `dcn`, `fr`, `br`, `sr`, `prof`

- **France:** `m`, `mme`, `mlle`, `autre`

- **Germany:** `herr`, `frau`, `prof`, `dr`

- **Austria:** `herr`, `frau`

- **Canada (French):** `m`, `mme`, `mlle`, `autre`

SupporterPostRequest.description: Represents the personal data of the supporter.

phone.description:
Supporter's phone number. Maximum 20 characters.

Only included if the campaign setting “Ask for phone number” is enabled.

Required if the campaign is configured to require the supporter to provide their phone number.

title.description:
Supporter's title in lowercase. Available options depend on the campaign settings. Available for the following countries:

- **United Kingdom:** `mr`, `mrs`, `miss`, `ms`, `mx`, `sir`, `dr`, `rev`, `dcn`, `fr`, `br`, `sr`, `prof`

- **France:** `m`, `mme`, `mlle`, `autre`

- **Germany:** `herr`, `frau`, `prof`, `dr`

- **Austria:** `herr`, `frau`

- **Canada (French):** `m`, `mme`, `mlle`, `autre`

SupporterRequest.description: Represents the personal data of the supporter. Only the specified parameters are updated, the others remain unchanged.

created_at.description: Timestamp in ISO 8601 format, indicating when the supporter was created, in UTC.

email.description: Email address associated with the supporter.

livemode.description: Test mode indicator. `true` for donations in live mode, `false` for donations in test mode.

data.description: An array containing the entity records, paginated by any request parameters.

has_more.description: Indicates whether there are more records available. For `starting_after`, it shows that there is a page with older records. For `ending_before`, it indicates that there is a page with newer records.

SupportersResponse.description: Provides a paginated response for supporters.

email.description: Email address used for `email` sharing type.

TributeRecipientResponse.description: Contains details about the tribute recipient.

honoree.description: Name of the person honored or remembered.

message.description: Custom message included in the tribute.

TributeSharingResponse.description: Defines the sharing options for a tribute.

campaign.description: Campaign ID. Must belong to the account that owns the API key, otherwise an error will occur. Must be active and accept money-based donations, otherwise an error will occur.

designation.description:
The ID of the fund, program, or initiative the donation goes to. You can use the ID of any designation created in your account, whether or not it is linked to a campaign.
Only one designation can be set for a single donation. To create multiple donations with different designations, make separate API calls.
You can find the ID in the [Designations section of the Dashboard](https://dashboard.fundraiseup.com/designations).

UpdateDonationRequest.description: Contains the request parameters for updating a donation.

campaign.description: Campaign ID. Must belong to the account that owns the API key, otherwise an error will occur. The campaign must be active and accept money-based donations, otherwise an error will occur.

code.description: Identifier of up to 150 characters. Does not need to be unique.

description.example: I'm raising money to help protect penguins and their habitat. Join me!

name.description: The title of the Fundraiser, used as its main heading.

slug.description: Unique identifier for the Fundraiser within the account or subaccount. The slug is not shared across accounts or subaccounts and must be unique within each. Can include up to 25 letters, numbers, underscores, or hyphens.

UpdateFundraiserRequest.description: Contains the request parameters required for updating a Fundraiser.

campaign.description: The `utm_campaign` value, if available. Shows the name of the marketing campaign.

content.description: The `utm_content` value, if available. Identifies which link or ad variation was clicked.

medium.description: The `utm_medium` value, if available. Shows the type of marketing channel.

source.description: The `utm_source` value, if available. Shows where the traffic came from.
